dialogue.text: Subject is Margaret Wu, age 45, visiting from an isolated community that still practices fixed identity. She's having a catalytic reaction to the uncertainty field.
Margaret Wu. Accountant. Mother of two. Presbyterian. Born March 15, 2078. Blood type O positive. I know exactly who I am.
My daughter. She lives here now. Changed her name to Flux. Says she's different people on different days. I came to bring her home, but this place... it's wrong.
I was you. Marcus Stone, engineer, grandfather. Knew exactly who I was for 73 years. Nearly created a certainty cascade just like this.
Margaret, what if we try something small? Instead of being Margaret-accountant-mother-Presbyterian, what if you were just Margaret-who-misses-her-daughter?
I'm your daughter. Always have been. Just more of your daughter than one shape can hold.

visual_elements.frozen_uncertainty: Fluid art and cafés locked rigid
visual_elements.mathematical_nature: Trees and grass in perfect grids

psychological_notes: Certainty as pathology in uncertainty-based society. Reality itself rejects rigid identity. Crisis intervention through gentle expansion rather than forced change. Certainty survivors as peer counselors. Family relationships strained by paradigm differences.
philosophical_underpinning: Extreme certainty creates reality distortions—universe requires flexibility
therapeutic_direction: Emergency intervention for certainty-induced reality crisis
